--- title: 'The Benefit of Talking to the "Non-Datas"' date: '2022-08-04' author: "Caro Buck" format: html draft: true toc: true execute: freeze: auto --- Why is it important to talk to people about data? Great question, I'd love to tell you. ![](imgs/banner.png){fig-alt="a hand-drawn banner of confetti"} #### Hello + Welcome to the party! Quick introduction for context: I'm Caro (short for Caroline) and I'm a data scientist at a marketing agency working on a creative tech team. Meaning that I don't do much traditional marketing analytics, moreover my team makes cool data toys^[We make web apps, prototypes and more, and sometimes use tech and data in not-quite-conventional ways. ] and goes down a lot of weird rabbit holes. This article is about talking to people who think they're not data people. It's an invitation to a new kind of party- a data party! Like a good party invite, it's a lot more fun if you've got all the details down (unless surprise party, but someone else should have the details then). So, let's hop in! *** So, in 2020, we all kind of became arm chair experts... ::: {layout="[55,45]"} ::: {.div} If you were thinking COVID-19, then we are thinking the same thing. Data have always had (and still currently do have) a large impact in our lives, but the various impacts over time have not always been visible. Thanks to a global pandemic, data suddenly moved to the forefront and had a very visceral, real and obvious impact in our lives. Statistical jargon became commonplace in casual conversation and numbers, charts and case counts dictated what we should or shouldn't do, who we could see, where we could go. Being able to understand numbers and charts suddenly became crucial to navigate daily life. ::: :::{.div} ![](imgs/rconf_preso_article/Armchair_COVID.png){fig-alt="A hand-drawn navy and gold arm chair with a covid virus drawn on top." fig-height=350} ::: ::: *** #### Data (Mis)conceptions ::: {layout="[55,45]"} ::: {.div} The average person might have a lot of baggage surrounding data- we've been told (by media, math class, social media, etc.) that data are a bunch of numbers, maybe in table or chart format, and could be big, scary and/or intimidating. ::: ::: {.div} TODO insert pic here about what ppl think data are ::: ::: *** **So what are data?** Spoiler- all of those things! And so much more! Like in improv comedy, this is a ["yes, and..."](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yes,_and...) situation. Meaning that you take what others offer, and add something to the story. You may shape, refine and take things in a new direction, yet you meet the person where they're currently at. When talking to people about data, it's really important to understand what conceptions they currently have about data. In addition to the above, data are: * Creative! Despite what we might (think we) want, data are not always "right"- there's a lot more color involved, rather than just a simple black or white answer. * Scientific! While very creative, data are also a rigorous way to study the world around us and collect information. * Everywhere! The more you look, the more you see! This is what makes data really fun to talk about with other people- just ask my friends and family who've gotten an earful! Now that we've cleared that up, let's hop into this invitation- don't forget to RSVP! *** #### Who Let's quickly clarify who is a "data" person and who is a "non-data" person. You may have noticed the quotes- that's completely intentional. "Data" person and "non-data" person are usually self-designated labels, perhaps based on one's job function or how good they think they are at math. However, rather than this exclusive view, I believe that everyone can be (and is!) a data person; we all exist somewhere on a spectrum of data readiness and the goal is not to all exist in the same place, rather it is to realize that the spectrum exists, and we can all exist on it in our own place. ![We all exist somewhere along the data readiness spectrum, somewhere between Novice and Expert.](imgs/rconf_preso_article/Who_Slide_3.png){fig-alt="Handwritten arrow with Novice on left, Expert on right. Arrow with blue asterisk points closer to novice. Sencond arrow points closer to expert"} It is also worth noting that the line from novice to expert is very likely not a straight line. In reality, the journey to becoming an expert is filled with unexpected twists and turns- and usually once you reach "expert level", you really just realize how much more you still have to learn. There are also multiple paths to expert, and because we can all be experts existing in our own niche worlds, it's worthwhile to share what we know, to remember that not everyone is following us down the exact same niche rabbit holes. ![Lots of ways to be an expert (none superior over another).](imgs/rconf_preso_article/Who_Slide_4.png){fig-alt="Several handwritten, swirling arrows from Novice on left to Expert on right."} So when you're looking for people to talk to about data: look around, it's likely that you could talk with anyone. Perhaps holler at a friend or roommate, or if you work in a large organization, perhaps talk with folks not on your team, or those you work with obliquely. *** #### What Now that we know who's invited to this party, what should we talk about? What to say when it comes to data can often depend on who we are talking to and where they are at on the data spectrum. For instance, maybe the person has a decent grasp of data things and we're going full on theme party (perhaps into the weeds on a fancy AI model). Or maybe we're staying a bit more high level with some small talk party chatter (perhaps getting excited about an interesting data journalism article you saw float by on Twitter recently). The "what" could be educational, entertaining, or both- it depends on the rest of the party invitation. One way to think about the "what" is to visualize it on a 2x2 grid. Let's take music as a category example and see what fits into each quadrant. ![Examples of what to talk about at your data party.](imgs/rconf_preso_article/XY_Axis_Slide_Filled_In.png){fig-alt="Handwritten xy-axis chart. X axis goes from Less Technical on left to More Technical on right, Y axis goes from Personal on bottom to General on top. Quadrants are filled in; upper left says Music Borders; Upper right says Gold Record Data Art; Lower left says Spotify Wrapped; Lower right says How Bad is you streaming music?"} Let's start with [Spotify Wrapped](https://newsroom.spotify.com/2021-12-01/the-wait-is-over-your-spotify-2021-wrapped-is-here/) in the lower left quadrant. You've probably seen Spotify's end of year recap over the past few years; it's a fun way to see what you (and your friends) have been listening to the past year. Under the hood, the data is pretty simple, it's essentially just counts of how many times a song (or artist or album or genre) was streamed. It's personal and easy to connect to because it's your music, you did the listening over the past year! The familiarity and simplicity of Spotify wrapped make it a great starting conversation for a data party. Moving up a quadrant, The Pudding's [Music Borders](https://pudding.cool/2018/06/music-map/?date=202106)^[Side note, if you haven't heard of [The Pudding](https://pudding.cool/) before, please go check them out. They make some really [cool](https://pudding.cool/2021/01/cool/) stuff. ] is also very approachable for data party conversation. Similar to Spotify Wrapped, the data under the hood are stream counts, but this project takes it up a notch by comparing recent top songs around the country and world. Though not necessarily personal to your own music tastes, it is interesting to explore what's popular in other parts of the world. Moving right, Nadieh Bremer's [Gold Record Data Art](https://www.visualcinnamon.com/portfolio/sony-music-data-art/) is a beautiful visualization of music related data. It is more technically complex because it incorporates a few different data sources, from streaming data to song-specific data (including amplitude, frequency and time). Though still very approachable, a visualization that combines multiple data sets in an elegant way may lead to a bigger data party conversation. Finally, in the bottom right quadrant we've got The Pudding's [Judge My Spotify](https://pudding.cool/2021/10/judge-my-music/) AI tool that will roast you for your music choices. It's hilarious, fun and customized to your own listening history, and under the hood there's a complex machine learning model you could unpack in a more detailed data party. *** #### Where + When ::: {layout="[55,45]"} ::: {.div} lol always and forever consider where people encounter data/viz Consider: Is this a last minute backyard hangout or a wedding planned months in advance? The where/when and what might also inform the others. E.g. if you want/need to deep dive on something to bridge understanding/knowledge gap, it makes sense to set up time in advance to discuss, so the audience has some sense of what they are getting into. If you're casually bringing it up in a way to entertain/show another side of data (e.g. a new/unexpected place to find data, or a creative data use), the where/when might be over lunch, or a brief meeting in a hallway, etc ::: ::: {.div} ![](imgs/Where_When.png){fig-alt="White background with confetti in corners; yellow cocktail table drawn on left, and calendar of July on right"} ::: ::: #### Why ## {background-image="imgs/Sci_Art.png" fig-alt="White background with confetti in corners, equation of Data=Science+Art handwritten on slide"} ::: {.notes} like mentioned at beginning, data are a lot more than what we might think about. data are science, and art, AND ACCESSIBILITY TOOL. ::: ## {background-image="imgs/Why_Blank.png" fig-alt="White background with confetti in corners"} :::{.fragment .fade-out .absolute top="25%" right="40%" width="500" height="800"} ![](imgs/Penguin.png){fig-alt="hand drawn penguin"} ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out .absolute top="10%" width="50%"} Penguins come in all shapes and sizes. Gentoo penguins tend to have the longest flipper length, on average, at **217.2 mm**, compared to Adelie (**190.0 mm**) and Chinstrap (**195.8 mm**) penguins. ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out .absolute bottom="30%"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` ── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.2 ```{.r .cell-code} palmerpenguins::penguins %>% group_by(species) %>% summarise(across(ends_with('mm'), ~ mean(.x, na.rm = TRUE))) %>% pivot_longer(2:4) %>% mutate(name=str_sub(name,1,-4)) %>% ggplot(aes(x=value,y=species,fill=species,label=scales::number(value,.1,suffix=' mm'))) + geom_col(position = 'dodge',color='black') + geom_label(fill='white',hjust=-.1,size=5) + facet_grid(name~.,scales = 'free_y') + scale_fill_manual(values = c('#FFE330','#00D1D9','#015377')) + theme_bw() + scale_x_continuous(limits = c(0,300)) + labs(title='Penguin Measurements by Species', x='Length (mm)',y='') + theme(legend.position = 'None', strip.text.y = element_text(angle=0,size=20), axis.text = element_text(size=18), axis.text.x = element_text(size = 18), axis.text.y = element_text(size=18), title = element_text(face='bold',size=26)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](20220804-rconf_preso_article_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){fig-align='center' fig-alt='Column chart of penguin flipper and bill measurements by species' width=960} ::: ::: ::: ::: ::: {.notes} you could go out an count penguins all day, and maybe that's what you do. but that's not what I'm gonna do. I rely on others data collection to learn new stuff this is just one example of how data itself can be used as an accessibility tool. numbers themselves can be a way to summarise information, and if we show numbers/data in a particular way, it can make the info more (or less) clear and accessible to folks. learn not just about penguins, but also able to interpret current events in world (e.g. covid charts) ::: ## {background-image="imgs/How.png" fig-alt="White background with confetti in corners, and a hand drawn newsletter, headphones and book."} :::{.absolute top="80%" left="10%"} [Sign up for Washington Post's Newsletter](https://www.washingtonpost.com/newsletters/how-to-read-this-chart/){style="font-size: x-large;"} ::: :::{.absolute top="80%" left="45%"} [Find a Podcast](https://towardsdatascience.com/5-data-science-podcasts-you-should-be-listening-to-72d8efd0b9ec){style="font-size: x-large;"} ::: :::{.absolute top="80%" left="75%"} [Read Janelle Shane's Book](https://www.janelleshane.com/book-you-look-like-a-thing){style="font-size: x-large;"} ::: ::: {.notes} you might be wondering, how do I get started? maybe you're ready to go, maybe you want some more prep. here are some refs to check out for inspiration or other "what"s to talk about w/ ppl ::: ## {background-image="imgs/How2.png" fig-alt="White background with confetti in corners and hand drawn person standing in the middle with a text bubble that says 'data'."} ::: {.notes} but my main advice? just go for it. just get started? may very likey feel awk, but just need to jump in and do it ::: #### Ending on a story TODO add pic for side by side (add legend too? double stack it) ::: {.notes} so, a story for why it's selfishly good to talk to "non datas"... back near beg of covid, I came across GL's data portraits and wanted to do something similar for my team. thought would be fun desk name tag for when we went back to office soon (spoiler, we never went back to office) but, fun to make and really fun to share w/ my team and guess who's who. fun to get to know each other in a way that wasn't strictly related to work, while working remotely. word got around about these and creative lead "you're gonna share w/ the whole C team" me: "really?!?" so I did. it was amazing to be able to share something very data driven, that was also very creative. (they didn't realize data could be so much more than reporting/analytics. and when others see the inspiration/possibilities, we can do cooler things with data!!) So, we, data people can selfishly do cooler things when others realize our powers and are willing to let data out of the box ::: ## {background-image="imgs/Ty_And_Question.png" fig-alt="White background with confetti in corners; 'Thank you' and 'Questions?' written on the slide."} #### PS: You *totally* have something worthwhile to share While preparing to speak at the conference, I came across this article about the [value of publishing your work](https://github.com/readme/guides/publishing-your-work) by Aaron Francis. ::: {style="font-size: 1.8em; font-style:bold;"} "They think that they're not doing anything interesting because they assume that everyone knows as much as they do...
As you become more of an expert, your quality bar gets higher and higher and you forget that everything you know is not known by everyone." ::: [-Aaron Francis]{style="font-size: xxx-large;"} to set us up for this talk, I want to share this quote as a little inspo content. we're all "masters" of something (master being a term that exists on a spectrum and can be loosely defined) sometimes we forget just how much we know, or we might be "masters" of different things, and it's worthwhile to remember our blind spots and share what we do know. everyone has something to share- don't sit out there and think u have nothing Thanks for coming to my party! Go do your own parties now! If you want to talk more, holler @ [carobuck.com](https://carobuck.com/)
